courses.title: Algorithms
courses.description: Presents the mathematical techniques used for the design and analysis of computer algorithms. Focuses on algorithmic design paradigms and techniques for analyzing the correctness, time, and space complexity of algorithms. Topics may include asymptotic notation, recurrences, loop invariants, Hoare triples, sorting and searching, advanced data structures, lower bounds, hashing, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, graph algorithms, and NP-completeness.
courses.reason: Foundational course essential for understanding algorithmic principles critical in NLP and data science, scheduled early to serve as a prerequisite for advanced courses.

courses.title: Essentials of Data Science
courses.description: Introduces students to the core tasks in data science, including data collection, storage, tidying, transformation, processing, management, and modeling for the purpose of extracting knowledge from raw observations. Programming is a cross-cutting aspect of the course. Offers students an opportunity to gain experience with data science tasks and tools through short assignments. Includes a term project based on real-world data.
courses.reason: Provides a broad foundation in data science core tasks, necessary for subsequent machine learning and NLP courses, scheduled early for foundational knowledge.

courses.title: Supervised Machine Learning and Learning Theory
courses.description: Introduces supervised machine learning, which is the study and design of algorithms that enable computers/machines to learn from experience or data, given examples of data with a known outcome of interest. Offers a broad view of models and algorithms for supervised decision making. Discusses the methodological foundations behind the models and the algorithms, as well as issues of practical implementation and use, and techniques for assessing the performance. Includes a term project involving programming and/or work with real-world data sets. Requires proficiency in a programming language such as Python, R, or MATLAB.
courses.reason: Critical for understanding machine learning techniques that underpin NLP models; scheduled after foundational courses to build on core data science skills.

courses.title: Unsupervised Machine Learning and Data Mining
courses.description: Introduces unsupervised machine learning and data mining, which is the process of discovering and summarizing patterns from large amounts of data, without examples of data with a known outcome of interest. Offers a broad view of models and algorithms for unsupervised data exploration. Discusses the methodological foundations behind the models and the algorithms, as well as issues of practical implementation and use, and techniques for assessing the performance. Includes a term project involving programming and/or work with real-life data sets. Requires proficiency in a programming language such as Python, R, or MATLAB.
courses.reason: Enhances understanding of unsupervised learning techniques vital for NLP tasks like clustering and topic modeling; scheduled alongside supervised learning for balanced exposure.

courses.title: Natural Language Processing
courses.description: Provides an introduction to the computational modeling of human language, the ongoing effort to create computer programs that can communicate with people in natural language, and current applications of the natural language field, such as automated document classification, intelligent query processing, and information extraction. Topics include computational models of grammar and automatic parsing, statistical language models and the analysis of large text corpuses, natural language semantics and programs that understand language, models of discourse structure, and language use by intelligent agents. Course work includes formal and mathematical analysis of language models, and implementation of working programs that analyze and interpret natural language text.
courses.reason: Central to the student's goal of becoming a data scientist in NLP; scheduled after foundational courses to ensure prerequisites are met, and to provide specialized NLP knowledge.

courses.title: Applied Natural Language Processing
courses.description: Provides hands-on instruction in natural language processing designed for applied AI. Offers students an opportunity to obtain real-world experience in crafting and refining NLP solutions in a project-based format and solving challenges that mirror industry and research scenarios. Emphasizes applied projects over pure theory.
courses.reason: Builds practical NLP skills through applied projects, complementing theoretical knowledge from CS6120, scheduled after core NLP course.

courses.title: Deep Learning
courses.description: Introduces deep learning, including the statistical learning framework, empirical risk minimization, loss function selection, fully connected layers, convolutional layers, pooling layers, batch normalization, multilayer perceptrons, convolutional neural networks, autoencoders, U-nets, residual networks, gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, backpropagation, autograd, visualization of neural network features, robustness and adversarial examples, interpretability, continual learning, and applications in computer vision and natural language processing. Assumes students already have a basic knowledge of machine learning, optimization, linear algebra, and statistics.
courses.reason: Advanced course essential for mastering deep learning techniques used in modern NLP models like transformers; scheduled last to build on prior ML knowledge.

courses.title: Applied Deep Learning
courses.description: Offers an advanced exploration of the theoretical foundations, architectures, and techniques essential for the design and optimization of deep learning models. Broadly discusses convolutional and recurrent neural networks, attention mechanisms, generative models, and transformer networks. Offers hands-on experience in implementing, optimizing, and deploying deep learning solutions to real-world problems. Highlights current challenges and the latest trends in the field.
courses.reason: Provides applied, cutting-edge deep learning techniques relevant for NLP applications like transformers and language models; scheduled in the final semester for advanced specialization.

courses.title: Data Science Capstone
courses.description: Offers students a capstone opportunity to practice data science skills learned in previous courses and to build a portfolio. Students practice visualization, data wrangling, and machine learning skills by applying them to semester-long term projects on real-world data. Students may either propose their own projects or choose from a selection of industry options. Emphasizes the overall data science process, including identification of the scientific problem, selection of appropriate machine learning methods, and visualization and communication of results. Lectures may include additional topics, including visualization, communication, and data science ethics.
courses.reason: Final project consolidating all learned skills, including NLP, machine learning, and deep learning, scheduled at the end of the program.

reason_behind_planning: The plan begins with foundational courses in algorithms and core data science tasks in Semester 1 to establish a strong technical base. Semester 2 builds on these with supervised and unsupervised machine learning, essential for understanding NLP models. Semester 3 introduces the core NLP course (CS6120) and applied NLP (INPR6620), providing both theoretical and practical NLP skills, scheduled after prerequisites are met. The final semester emphasizes advanced deep learning techniques (CS7150 and INPR6640), which are crucial for state-of-the-art NLP models like transformers, along with the capstone project to synthesize all skills. Courses are grouped to balance workload, respect prerequisites, and progressively deepen expertise in NLP and deep learning. Electives are selected to complement core courses, focusing on applied NLP and deep learning, ensuring at least three electives are included. The schedule respects credit constraints, semester limits, and prerequisite sequencing, providing a comprehensive pathway toward becoming a data scientist specialized in NLP.

courses.title: Computer Vision
courses.description: Introduces topics such as image formation, segmentation, feature extraction, matching, shape recovery, dynamic scene analysis, and object recognition. Computer vision brings together imaging devices, computers, and sophisticated algorithms to solve problems in industrial inspection, autonomous navigation, human-computer interfaces, medicine, image retrieval from databases, realistic computer graphics rendering, document analysis, and remote sensing. The goal of computer vision is to make useful decisions about real physical objects and scenes based on sensed images. Computer vision is an exciting but disorganized field that builds on very diverse disciplines such as image processing, statistics, pattern recognition, control theory, system identification, physics, geometry, computer graphics, and learning theory. Requires good programming experience in Matlab or C++.

courses.reason: Foundational algorithms are scheduled early to build necessary analytical skills for subsequent courses, and they are core to understanding complex topics in computer vision and machine learning.

courses.description: Introduces students to the core tasks in data science, including data collection, storage, tidying, transformation, processing, management, and modeling for the purpose of extracting knowledge from raw observations. Programming is a cross-cutting aspect of the course. Offers students an opportunity to gain experience with data science tasks and tools through short assignments. Includes a term project based on real-world data.
courses.reason: This course provides essential data science skills necessary for understanding and manipulating data, which are critical for computer vision applications.

courses.title: Supervised Machine Learning and Learning Theory
courses.description: Introduces supervised machine learning, which is the study and design of algorithms that enable computers/machines to learn from experience or data, given examples of data with a known outcome of interest. Offers a broad view of models and algorithms for supervised decision making. Discusses the methodological foundations behind the models and the algorithms, as well as issues of practical implementation and use, and techniques for assessing the performance. Includes a term project involving programming and/or work with real-world data sets. Requires proficiency in a programming language such as Python, R, or MATLAB.
courses.reason: Supervised learning is fundamental for many computer vision tasks like classification and object detection, making this course essential early in the plan.

courses.title: Unsupervised Machine Learning and Data Mining
courses.description: Introduces unsupervised machine learning and data mining, which is the process of discovering and summarizing patterns from large amounts of data, without examples of data with a known outcome of interest. Offers a broad view of models and algorithms for unsupervised data exploration. Discusses the methodological foundations behind the models and the algorithms, as well as issues of practical implementation and use, and techniques for assessing the performance. Includes a term project involving programming and/or work with real-life data sets. Requires proficiency in a programming language such as Python, R, or MATLAB.
courses.reason: Unsupervised learning complements supervised methods and is crucial for tasks like clustering, feature extraction, and understanding image data in computer vision.

courses.title: Pattern Recognition and Computer Vision
courses.description: Introduces fundamental techniques for low-level and high-level computer vision. Examines image formation, early processing, boundary detection, image segmentation, texture analysis, shape from shading, photometric stereo, motion analysis via optic flow, object modeling, shape description, and object recognition (classification). Discusses models of human vision (gestalt effects, texture perception, subjective contours, visual illusions, apparent motion, mental rotations, and cyclopean vision). Requires knowledge of linear algebra.
courses.reason: This elective provides foundational computer vision techniques necessary for advanced topics and research in the field.

courses.title: Advanced Computer Vision
courses.description: Offers students an opportunity to obtain practical knowledge in computer vision and to develop skills for being a successful researcher in this field. The goal of the field of computer vision is to make useful decisions about real physical objects and scenes based on sensed images. Achieving this goal requires obtaining and using descriptions (models) of the sensors and the world. Computer vision is an exciting field that builds on very diverse disciplines such as image processing, statistics, pattern recognition, control theory and system identification, physics, geometry, computer graphics, and machine learning. Course material includes state-of-the-art in the field, current research trends, and algorithms and their applications, with an emphasis on the mathematical methods used.
courses.reason: This elective deepens understanding of practical and research aspects of computer vision, essential for specialization.

courses.title: Deep Learning
courses.description: Introduces deep learning, including the statistical learning framework, empirical risk minimization, loss function selection, fully connected layers, convolutional layers, pooling layers, batch normalization, multilayer perceptrons, convolutional neural networks, autoencoders, U-nets, residual networks, gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, backpropagation, autograd, visualization of neural network features, robustness and adversarial examples, interpretability, continual learning, and applications in computer vision and natural language processing. Assumes students already have a basic knowledge of machine learning, optimization, linear algebra, and statistics.
courses.reason: Deep learning is central to modern computer vision systems; scheduling it in the final semester allows for comprehensive understanding and application.

courses.title: Data Science Capstone
courses.description: Offers students a capstone opportunity to practice data science skills learned in previous courses and to build a portfolio. Students practice visualization, data wrangling, and machine learning skills by applying them to semester-long term projects on real-world data. Students may either propose their own projects or choose from a selection of industry options. Emphasizes the overall data science process, including identification of the scientific problem, selection of appropriate machine learning methods, and visualization and communication of results. Lectures may include additional topics, including visualization, communication, and data science ethics.
courses.reason: The capstone consolidates learning, emphasizing practical skills in applying computer vision and data science techniques to real-world problems.

reason_behind_planning: This plan was structured to ensure all core courses are scheduled early, respecting prerequisites and building foundational knowledge necessary for advanced topics. The first semester introduces essential algorithms and data science skills, establishing a base for machine learning courses in the second semester. The second semester continues with supervised and unsupervised learning, which are fundamental for understanding computer vision techniques. The third semester introduces core computer vision electives, providing specialized knowledge and research skills. The final semester emphasizes deep learning applications in computer vision, culminating in a capstone project that integrates all learned skills. Workload is balanced across semesters, with each semester containing exactly 8 credits, and electives are chosen to deepen expertise in computer vision without overloading. The sequence respects course prerequisites and ensures a logical progression from foundational to advanced topics, preparing the student for a specialization in computer vision with a strong theoretical and practical foundation.

courses.title: Programming Design Paradigm
courses.description: Introduces modern program design paradigms. Starts with functional program design, introducing the notion of a design recipe. The latter consists of two parts: a task organization (ranging from the description of data to the creation of a test suite) and a data-oriented approach to the organization of programs (ranging from atomic data to self-referential data definitions and functions as data). The course then progresses to object-oriented design, explaining how it generalizes and contrasts with functional design. In addition to studying program design, students also have an opportunity to practice pair-programming and public code review techniques, as found in industry today.
courses.reason: Foundational course to develop essential programming skills necessary for all subsequent courses.

courses.title: Database Management Systems
courses.description: Introduces relational database management systems as a class of software systems. Prepares students to be sophisticated users of database management systems. Covers design theory, query language, and performance/tuning issues. Topics include relational algebra, SQL, stored procedures, user-defined functions, cursors, embedded SQL programs, client-server interfaces, entity-relationship diagrams, normalization, B-trees, concurrency, transactions, database security, constraints, object-relational DBMSs, and specialized engines such as spatial, text, XML conversion, and time series. Includes exercises using a commercial relational or object-relational database management system.
courses.reason: Essential for understanding data storage and retrieval, crucial for NLP and big data applications.

courses.title: Algorithms
courses.description: Presents the mathematical techniques used for the design and analysis of computer algorithms. Focuses on algorithmic design paradigms and techniques for analyzing the correctness, time, and space complexity of algorithms. Topics may include asymptotic notation, recurrences, loop invariants, Hoare triples, sorting and searching, advanced data structures, lower bounds, hashing, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, graph algorithms, and NP-completeness.
courses.reason: Provides the algorithmic foundation necessary for understanding complex models in NLP and large-scale data processing.

courses.title: Natural Language Processing
courses.description: Provides an introduction to the computational modeling of human language, the ongoing effort to create computer programs that can communicate with people in natural language, and current applications of the natural language field, such as automated document classification, intelligent query processing, and information extraction. Topics include computational models of grammar and automatic parsing, statistical language models and the analysis of large text corpuses, natural language semantics and programs that understand language, models of discourse structure, and language use by intelligent agents. Course work includes formal and mathematical analysis of language models, and implementation of working programs that analyze and interpret natural language text.
courses.reason: Core course to establish NLP fundamentals, essential for specialization in LLMs.

courses.title: Foundations for Generative AI
courses.description: Offers students an opportunity to obtain both the theoretical foundation and practical skills to understand, analyze, and apply generative AI techniques effectively. Begins with foundational concepts in AI and machine learning; progresses to advanced natural language processing, transformer models, and large language models; and concludes with cutting-edge techniques like prompt engineering, domain-specific adaptations, and retrieval-augmented generation.
courses.reason: Builds advanced knowledge in generative AI and LLMs, directly aligning with student goals.

courses.title: Large Language Models
courses.description: Explores the foundations, methodologies, and applications of large language models (LLMs), cutting-edge systems reshaping the field of artificial intelligence. Covers core topics including model architectures, training objectives, fine-tuning strategies, prompt engineering, evaluation metrics, and challenges such as bias, fairness, and interpretability. Highlights real-world uses of LLMs in tasks such as text generation, translation, summarization, and reasoning. Offers opportunities to examine recent research and trends driving the rapid evolution of LLMs. Emphasizes both theoretical understanding and practical applications using widely adopted tools and libraries for developing and deploying LLMs. Encourages critical thinking about the societal implications of deploying these models at scale.
courses.reason: Critical elective to deepen expertise specifically in LLMs, aligning with long-term specialization goals.

courses.title: Deep Learning
courses.description: Introduces deep learning, including the statistical learning framework, empirical risk minimization, loss function selection, fully connected layers, convolutional layers, pooling layers, batch normalization, multilayer perceptrons, convolutional neural networks, autoencoders, U-nets, residual networks, gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, backpropagation, autograd, visualization of neural network features, robustness and adversarial examples, interpretability, continual learning, and applications in computer vision and natural language processing. Assumes students already have a basic knowledge of machine learning, optimization, linear algebra, and statistics.
courses.reason: Provides advanced deep learning techniques essential for state-of-the-art NLP models and LLMs.

Discusses the methodological foundations behind the models and the algorithms, as well as issues of practical implementation and use, and techniques for assessing the performance. Includes a term project involving programming and/or work with real-world data sets. Requires proficiency in a programming language such as Python, R, or MATLAB.
courses.reason: Enhances understanding of machine learning algorithms underpinning NLP and LLM training.

reason_behind_planning: This plan was structured to prioritize foundational knowledge early in the program, starting with core courses in programming design, databases, and algorithms in Semester 1. The plan avoids overloading in any single semester and ensures all core courses are completed early enough to allow for advanced electives later. This structure supports a comprehensive, balanced, and focused pathway toward the student's career goals in NLP, LLMs, and big data.

courses.title: Large-Scale Parallel Data Processing
courses.description: Covers big-data analysis techniques that scale out with increasing number of compute nodes, e.g., for cloud computing. Emphasizes approaches for problem and data partitioning that distribute work effectively, while keeping total cost for computation and data transfer low. Studies and analyzes deterministic and random algorithms from a variety of domains, including graphs, data mining, linear algebra, and information retrieval in terms of their cost, scalability, and robustness against skew. Course work emphasizes hands-on programming experience with modern state-of-the-art big-data processing technology. Students who do not meet course prerequisites may seek permission of instructor.
courses.reason: Key to mastering scalable data processing frameworks and cloud-based big data analysis.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Cloud Computing
courses.description: Covers fundamentals of cloud computing, including virtualization and containers, distributed file systems and object stores, infrastructure as a service platforms, open source cloud platforms, key big data platforms, and topics in data center scale systems. Combines classroom material delivered via lectures, readings from literature, student presentations, and a semester-long software project.
courses.reason: Provides essential knowledge of cloud infrastructure, vital for cloud data engineering and deployment.

courses.title: Data Science Engineering Methods and Tools
courses.description: Introduces the fundamental techniques for machine learning and data science engineering. Discusses a variety of machine learning algorithms, along with examples of their implementation, evaluation, and best practices. Lays the foundation of how learning models are derived from complex data pipelines, both algorithmically and practically. Topics include supervised learning (parametric/nonparametric algorithms, support vector machines, kernels, neural networks, deep learning) and unsupervised learning (clustering, dimensionality reduction, recommender systems). Based on numerous real-world case studies.
courses.reason: Builds expertise in data science methods, complementing large-scale data engineering skills.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming for Data Science
courses.description: Offers an introductory course on fundamentals of programming and data structures. Covers lists, arrays, trees, hash tables, etc.; program design, programming practices, testing, debugging, maintainability, data collection techniques, and data cleaning and preprocessing. Includes a class project, where students use the concepts covered to collect data from the web, clean and preprocess the data, and make it ready for analysis.

courses.title: Engineering of Big-Data Systems
courses.description: Introduces a general framework for thinking about big data. Services such as Web analytics and intelligent e-commerce have promoted a rapid increase in the volume of data generated, analyzed, and archived. In order to solve the problems related to big data, a newer type of database product has emerged. Covers how to apply technologies like Hadoop, Accumulo, MongoDB, and various NoSQL databases to build simple, robust, and efficient systems to manage and analyze big data. Also describes an easy approach to big data systems that can be built and run by a small team of students. Guides students through the theory of big data systems, how to implement them in practice, and how to deploy and operate them once they are built.
courses.reason: Concludes with practical big data system design, essential for cloud-based data engineering roles.

reason_behind_planning: This schedule was structured to prioritize foundational core courses early in the program, ensuring prerequisites are respected and establishing a solid knowledge base in programming, databases, and algorithms. The first semester introduces core programming and database management, which are essential for understanding large-scale data processing later. The second semester emphasizes scalable data processing techniques and algorithms, critical for handling big data workloads. The third semester shifts focus to cloud computing fundamentals and data science methods, aligning with the goal of becoming a cloud data specialist and data engineer. The final semester reinforces programming and big data system engineering, integrating practical skills necessary for large-scale cloud data engineering roles. Elective courses were strategically placed in the later semesters to deepen knowledge in cloud computing, data science, and big data systems, supporting the student's career goal. The workload is balanced at 8 credits per semester, and all courses are scheduled respecting prerequisites and course availability constraints. The plan ensures all core courses are included exactly once, with electives selected to meet the minimum credit requirement, providing a comprehensive, balanced, and feasible pathway to the student's career objectives.

courses.title: Programming Design Paradigm
courses.description: Introduces modern program design paradigms. Starts with functional program design, introducing the notion of a design recipe. The course then progresses to object-oriented design, explaining how it generalizes and contrasts with functional design.
courses.reason: This foundational course is scheduled first to establish core programming skills essential for subsequent courses, especially data management and processing courses.

courses.title: Database Management Systems
courses.description: Introduces relational database management systems as a class of software systems. Covers design theory, query language, and performance/tuning issues.
courses.reason: Scheduling early to build core knowledge of databases, which is critical for data engineering and cloud data systems.

courses.title: Algorithms
courses.description: Presents the mathematical techniques used for the design and analysis of computer algorithms. Focuses on algorithmic design paradigms and techniques for analyzing correctness, time, and space complexity.
courses.reason: Placed early to develop problem-solving skills and understanding of efficient algorithms, which are vital for large-scale data processing.

courses.title: Large-Scale Parallel Data Processing
courses.description: Covers big-data analysis techniques that scale out with increasing number of compute nodes, emphasizing hands-on programming with modern big-data processing technology.
courses.reason: Scheduled after foundational courses to start introducing big data processing techniques relevant for cloud and large-scale data engineering.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Cloud Computing
courses.description: Covers fundamentals of cloud computing, virtualization, containers, distributed file systems, and key big data platforms.
courses.reason: Placed here to introduce cloud concepts after core programming, algorithms, and data processing courses, setting a foundation for cloud-focused electives.

courses.title: Enterprise Big Data and Data Engineering
courses.description: Focuses on designing and implementing large-scale data processing and storage systems for enterprise environments.
courses.reason: Scheduled here to deepen understanding of enterprise data engineering, complementing cloud fundamentals, and preparing for scalable system design.

courses.title: Applied Programming and Data Processing for AI
courses.description: Explores programming paradigms, mathematical foundations, and computational techniques for scientific computing and data-driven applications.
courses.reason: Placed in the final semester to consolidate programming skills with a focus on data processing and AI applications, supporting large-scale data engineering.

courses.title: Data Science Capstone
courses.description: Provides a capstone opportunity to practice data science skills learned in previous courses, including visualization, data wrangling, and machine learning.
courses.reason: Scheduled last to serve as a culminating project, applying all learned skills in a real-world context, essential for a comprehensive data engineering profile.

reason_behind_planning: This plan was structured to prioritize foundational courses early in the program, such as Programming Design Paradigm, Database Management Systems, and Algorithms, ensuring prerequisites are respected and core skills are established upfront. The first two semesters focus on core programming, algorithms, and data processing techniques, which are essential for understanding large-scale data systems. The third semester introduces cloud computing and enterprise data engineering electives, aligning with the goal of becoming a cloud data specialist and large-scale data engineer. These electives build on earlier courses, emphasizing scalable and distributed systems, cloud fundamentals, and enterprise data solutions. The final semester consolidates programming and data processing skills with applied techniques and culminates in a capstone project, providing practical experience and a portfolio showcasing expertise. The workload is balanced with 8 credits per semester, respecting constraints, and all core courses are included exactly once. Electives are chosen to complement and deepen knowledge in cloud, big data, and scalable system design, aligning with the student's career goals.

courses.title: Programming Design Paradigm
courses.description: Introduces modern program design paradigms. Starts with functional program design, introducing the notion of a design recipe. The latter consists of two parts: a task organization (ranging from the description of data to the creation of a test suite) and a data-oriented approach to the organization of programs (ranging from atomic data to self-referential data definitions and functions as data). The course then progresses to object-oriented design, explaining how it generalizes and contrasts with functional design. In addition to studying program design, students also have an opportunity to practice pair-programming and public code review techniques, as found in industry today.
courses.reason: Foundational course to develop strong programming and design skills essential for large-scale data engineering and cloud projects.

courses.title: Database Management Systems
courses.description: Introduces relational database management systems as a class of software systems. Prepares students to be sophisticated users of database management systems. Covers design theory, query language, and performance/tuning issues. Topics include relational algebra, SQL, stored procedures, user-defined functions, cursors, embedded SQL programs, client-server interfaces, entity-relationship diagrams, normalization, B-trees, concurrency, transactions, database security, constraints, object-relational DBMSs, and specialized engines such as spatial, text, XML conversion, and time series.
courses.reason: Critical for understanding data storage, retrieval, and management, which are core to data engineering and cloud data solutions.

courses.title: Algorithms
courses.description: Presents the mathematical techniques used for the design and analysis of computer algorithms. Focuses on algorithmic design paradigms and techniques for analyzing the correctness, time, and space complexity of algorithms. Topics may include asymptotic notation, recurrences, loop invariants, Hoare triples, sorting and searching, advanced data structures, lower bounds, hashing, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, graph algorithms, and NP-completeness.
courses.reason: Provides essential algorithmic foundations necessary for efficient data processing and system design in large-scale environments.

courses.title: Large-Scale Parallel Data Processing
courses.description: Covers big-data analysis techniques that scale out with increasing number of compute nodes, e.g., for cloud computing. Emphasizes approaches for problem and data partitioning that distribute work effectively, while keeping total cost for computation and data transfer low. Studies and analyzes deterministic and random algorithms from a variety of domains, including graphs, data mining, linear algebra, and information retrieval in terms of their cost, scalability, and robustness against skew. Course work emphasizes hands-on programming experience with modern state-of-the-art big-data processing technology.
courses.reason: Essential for understanding distributed data processing frameworks like Hadoop or Spark, vital for large-scale data engineering in cloud environments.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Cloud Computing
courses.description: Covers fundamentals of cloud computing, including virtualization and containers, distributed file systems and object stores, infrastructure as a service platforms, open source cloud platforms, key big data platforms, and topics in data center scale systems. Combines classroom material delivered via lectures, readings from literature, student presentations, and a semester-long software project.
courses.reason: Provides core knowledge of cloud infrastructure and services, crucial for a career as a cloud data specialist and data engineer.

courses.title: Building Scalable Distributed Systems
courses.description: Covers the essential elements of distributed, concurrent systems and builds upon that knowledge with engineering principles and practical experience with state-of-the-art technologies and methods for building scalable systems. Scalability is an essential quality of internet-facing systems and requires specialized skills and knowledge to build systems that scale at low cost.
courses.reason: Deepens understanding of distributed system design, scalability, and engineering principles necessary for cloud-based data solutions.

courses.title: Principles of Scalable Data Management: Theory, Algorithms, and Database Systems
courses.description: Covers the algorithms, core principles, and foundational concepts for managing data at scale. Topics include data models, query languages, query execution and optimization, complexity of query execution and query resilience, data stream processing, parallel data processing, transactions, linear vs. relational algebra, factorizations, and uncertainty in logic. Offers students an opportunity to gain hands-on experience through smaller assignments and a project.
courses.reason: Completes the core knowledge in scalable data management, essential for advanced data engineering roles.

courses.title: Engineering of Big-Data Systems
courses.description: Introduces a general framework for thinking about big data. Services such as Web analytics and intelligent e-commerce have promoted a rapid increase in the volume of data generated, analyzed, and archived. In order to solve the problems related to big data, a newer type of database product has emerged. Covers how to apply technologies like Hadoop, Accumulo, MongoDB, and various NoSQL databases to build simple, robust, and efficient systems to manage and analyze big data. Also describes an easy approach to big data systems that can be built and run by a small team of students. Guides students through the theory of big data systems, how to implement them in practice, and how to deploy and operate them once they are built.
courses.prerequisites: Information Systems Program 6205 Graduate B- Or Information Systems Program 6250 Graduate B- Or Information Systems Program 7390 Graduate B- Or Computer Systems Engineering 6220 Graduate B-

reason_behind_planning: This plan begins with foundational courses in programming design and database management to establish core technical skills. The second semester focuses on algorithms and large-scale data processing techniques, building the necessary computational and distributed data processing expertise. The third semester introduces cloud computing fundamentals and scalable distributed systems, aligning with the goal to specialize in cloud data solutions and large-scale system design. The final semester consolidates knowledge with advanced principles of scalable data management, fulfilling core requirements and preparing the student for practical, real-world applications. Electives are strategically placed in the third semester to deepen cloud and distributed system understanding, which are critical for a career as a cloud data specialist and large-scale data engineer. Prerequisites are respected by sequencing courses in logical order, and workload is balanced across semesters to ensure manageable progression. The total credits are maintained within the specified range, and all core courses are included exactly once, with electives chosen to complement and extend core knowledge.

courses.title: Programming Design Paradigm
courses.description: Introduces modern program design paradigms. Starts with functional program design, introducing the notion of a design recipe. The course then progresses to object-oriented design, explaining how it generalizes and contrasts with functional design.
courses.reason: This foundational course is scheduled first to establish core programming skills necessary for subsequent courses. It has no prerequisites and sets the stage for advanced data management and processing topics.

courses.title: Database Management Systems
courses.description: Introduces relational database management systems, covering design theory, SQL, normalization, and performance tuning.
courses.reason: Scheduled early to build essential database knowledge critical for data engineering tasks, including data modeling and querying, which are fundamental for large-scale data systems.

courses.title: Algorithms
courses.description: Presents mathematical techniques for designing and analyzing algorithms, including data structures, sorting, graph algorithms, and NP-completeness.
courses.reason: Placed early to develop algorithmic thinking and problem-solving skills necessary for scalable data processing and system optimization.

courses.title: Large-Scale Parallel Data Processing
courses.description: Covers big-data analysis techniques that scale out with compute nodes, emphasizing hands-on programming with modern big-data tech.
courses.reason: Scheduled after foundational courses to introduce practical skills in large-scale data processing, aligning with the goal of becoming a large-scale data engineer.

courses.title: Engineering of Big-Data Systems
courses.description: Introduces a framework for big data systems, covering technologies like Hadoop, MongoDB, and NoSQL databases.
courses.reason: Placed here to deepen understanding of big data system engineering, complementing previous courses with practical deployment knowledge.

courses.title: Data Science Engineering Methods and Tools
courses.description: Covers machine learning techniques, data pipelines, and real-world case studies.
courses.reason: Scheduled to build data science and machine learning skills, essential for a cloud data specialist role, and to diversify technical expertise.

courses.title: Big-Data System Engineering Using Scala
courses.description: Focuses on functional programming with Scala for big data platforms, sharing Java libraries.
courses.reason: Placed in the final semester to provide advanced programming skills tailored for scalable data systems, leveraging functional programming for efficiency.

courses.title: Principles of Scalable Data Management: Theory, Algorithms, and Database Systems
courses.description: Covers algorithms and principles for managing data at scale, including query optimization and data stream processing.
courses.reason: Scheduled last to solidify knowledge of scalable data management, aligning with the goal of becoming a large-scale data engineer and cloud data specialist.

reason_behind_planning: This plan begins with foundational courses in programming (CS5010) and databases (CS5200) to establish core technical skills. These are followed by an algorithm course (CS5800) and a big data processing course (CS6240), which are critical for understanding scalable data systems. The third semester introduces specialized electives—big data systems engineering (GSEN7250) and data science methods (GSEN6105)—to deepen expertise in big data infrastructure and machine learning, essential for cloud data roles. The final semester consolidates advanced programming with Scala (GSEN7200) and scalable data management principles (CS7240), preparing the student for practical deployment in large-scale, cloud-based environments. All prerequisites are respected, and courses are grouped to balance workload, with core courses early and electives later, ensuring a comprehensive, structured progression toward the student’s goals.

courses.title: Cybersecurity: Technologies, Threats, and Defenses
courses.description: Seeks to provide a systematic understanding of cyberspace technology and applications deployed in the global digital infrastructure. Covers topics in computer networks, server architectures, operating systems, and scripting. All the techniques and tools included in the course are oriented to serve as instruments of security administrators and cybersecurity professionals. Uses practical hands-on labs running on virtual machines and containers hosted in the cloud computing environment to train students. For that reason, a practical overview of virtualization technologies, containerization, and cloud computing models is provided.
courses.reason: This foundational course introduces core cybersecurity concepts and practical skills, setting the stage for advanced topics and electives.

courses.title: Cybersecurity Principles and Practices
courses.description: Introduces information security via concepts of confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Discusses ethical, legal, and privacy ramifications while reviewing various laws, such as the Patriot Act, the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, and the General Data Protection Regulation. Covers security methods, controls, procedures, economics of cybercrime, criminal procedure, and forensics.
courses.reason: This course provides essential security principles and legal context, crucial for understanding security practices in cloud environments and beyond.

courses.title: Computer System Security
courses.description: Offers a practical overview of enterprise computer security, operating systems security, and related topics. Applies concepts such as authentication, access control, integrity, and audit to the modern operating system. Discusses and demonstrates system, process, memory, and file system-level defenses—and the attacks against them. Also discusses topics in data security and virtualization. Uses hands-on labs to reinforce skills and provide practical experience.
courses.reason: This course deepens understanding of system security, essential for cloud security engineering, and builds on foundational security principles.

courses.title: Foundations of Software Security
courses.description: Provides an overview of various software security threats and some of the most effective countermeasures used to thwart both well-known and newly emerging software security threats. Introduces best practices and tools available to help minimize common software security attacks, recognizing that it is impossible to accomplish ‘perfect security’ in software. Also studies secure coding concepts, tools, and practices in a high-level programming language.
courses.reason: This course enhances knowledge of software vulnerabilities and secure coding, vital for developing secure cloud applications.

courses.title: Cloud Security Practices
courses.description: Introduces the fundamentals of cloud computing. Examines the strategies to implement security controls, perform risk assessments, and handle incident detection and response. Emphasizes maintenance of a business-minded security life cycle for cloud-based environments. Offers students an opportunity to obtain an understanding of various security challenges, threat models, and data privacy issues in regard to compliance and legal implications.
courses.reason: This elective directly supports the goal of becoming a cloud security engineer by focusing on cloud-specific security strategies.

courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: Studies the theory and practice of computer security, focusing on the security aspects of multiuser systems and the Internet. Introduces cryptographic tools, such as encryption, key exchange, hashing, and digital signatures in terms of their applicability to maintaining network security. Discusses security protocols for mobile networks. Topics include firewalls, viruses, Trojan horses, password security, biometrics, VPNs, and Internet protocols such as SSL, IPSec, PGP, SNMP, and others.
courses.reason: This course provides advanced network security knowledge, essential for securing cloud infrastructures and networks.

courses.title: Capstone Project
courses.description: Draws together candidates from diverse backgrounds (technical, legal, and/or law enforcement) in a collaborative activity to address one or more security issues from an integrated perspective. Requires a project proposal, generally industrially oriented, to be submitted and accepted prior to the semester in which the project is to be undertaken.
courses.reason: The capstone synthesizes all learned concepts and provides practical experience, preparing the student for a security engineering role.

courses.title: Network Structures and Cloud Computing
courses.description: Offers a practical foundation in cloud computing and hands-on experience with the tools used in cloud computing. Focuses on the fundamentals of cloud computing, the principal areas of cloud architectures, cloud security, cloud governance, cloud storage, cloud virtualization, and cloud capacity. Discusses the Internet evolution that led to cloud and how cloud applications revolutionized Web applications.
courses.reason: This elective consolidates cloud computing knowledge, critical for a cloud security engineer, and complements the capstone project.

reason_behind_planning: This plan was structured to prioritize foundational core courses early in the curriculum, ensuring prerequisites are respected and students gain essential cybersecurity knowledge upfront. The first semester includes the two core courses that establish fundamental concepts. The second semester introduces more specialized elective courses that build on these foundations, such as system security and software security, which are crucial for understanding complex security environments. The third semester focuses on advanced cloud security topics and network security, directly aligning with the goal of becoming a cloud security engineer. The final semester culminates with the capstone project, integrating all learned skills in a practical, industrially oriented activity, supported by a cloud computing infrastructure course. Workload is balanced across semesters with 8 credits each, and all courses are scheduled respecting prerequisites. The electives chosen support cloud security, network security, and practical cloud knowledge, essential for the student's career goal. No core courses are scheduled in the last semester except for the capstone, aligning with best practices for final project work. This structure ensures comprehensive coverage of necessary topics within the 4-semester timeframe, meeting credit requirements, and preparing the student for a specialized role in cloud security engineering.

courses.description: Creates the opportunity for competency in the development of information security policies and plans including controls for physical, software, and networks. Discusses different malicious attacks, such as viruses and Trojan horses, detection strategies, countermeasures, damage assessment, and control. Covers information system risk analysis and management, audits, and log files. Uses case studies, site visits, and works with commercial products.
courses.reason: This course deepens understanding of risk management, an essential skill for a cloud security engineer, and is scheduled after foundational courses.

Offers students an opportunity to obtain an understanding of various security challenges, threat models, and data privacy issues in regard to compliance and legal implications.
courses.reason: This elective builds on foundational cloud knowledge to focus specifically on security practices in cloud environments, crucial for a cloud security engineer.

Focuses on the fundamentals of cloud computing, the principal areas of cloud architectures, cloud security, cloud governance, cloud storage, cloud virtualization, and cloud capacity. Discusses the Internet evolution that led to cloud and how cloud applications revolutionized Web applications.
courses.reason: Enhances understanding of cloud architectures and security, reinforcing skills needed for a cloud security role.

courses.description: Draws together candidates from diverse backgrounds (technical, legal, and/or law enforcement) in a collaborative activity to address one or more security issues from an integrated perspective. Requires a project proposal, generally industrially oriented, to be submitted and accepted prior to the semester in which the project is to be undertaken.
courses.reason: This capstone synthesizes all learning, applying cybersecurity and cloud security principles in a practical project, ideally in the final semester.

courses.title: Zero Trust Architecture for Software Engineers
courses.description: Explores how to integrate Zero Trust security measures in software systems from the ground up to address evolving cybersecurity threats effectively. Focuses on the impact of Zero Trust principles on software design and deployment. Through class lectures, practical workshops, and collaborative projects, offers students an opportunity to obtain the skills to design, develop, and maintain secure software applications in various environments, including cloud-based and decentralized infrastructures. Intended for software engineers.
courses.reason: Provides advanced security architecture knowledge, critical for designing secure cloud systems, and is suitable for the final semester.

reason_behind_planning: This four-semester plan begins with foundational cybersecurity courses (CY5001 and CY5010) to establish core knowledge early. Semester 2 introduces risk management and fundamental cloud computing (CY5200 and CS6620), building the technical base needed for specialized cloud security courses. Semester 3 adds advanced cloud security practices (CY5065) and network/cloud architecture (GSEN6225), deepening expertise in cloud environments. The final semester culminates with the capstone project (CY7900) to integrate all skills practically, along with Zero Trust architecture (GSEN7300) to focus on modern security frameworks. Courses are grouped to respect prerequisites, balance workload, and progressively deepen knowledge, ensuring all core courses are included and elective courses support the goal of becoming a cloud security engineer.

courses.description: Seeks to help students to become aware of systems security issues and to gain a basic understanding of security. Presents the principal software and applications used in the Internet, discussing in detail the related vulnerabilities and how they are exploited. Also discusses programming vulnerabilities and how they are exploited. Examines protection and detection techniques. Includes a number of practical lab assignments as well as a discussion of current research in the field.
courses.reason: Provides insight into software vulnerabilities, an important aspect of cloud security and application defense strategies.

courses.reason: Final project synthesizing learning, demonstrating applied skills in cybersecurity and cloud security, essential for career readiness.

courses.description: Offers a practical foundation in cloud computing and hands-on experience with the tools used in cloud computing. Focuses on cloud architectures, security, governance, storage, virtualization, and the evolution of web applications.
courses.reason: Provides practical skills in cloud architectures and security, directly supporting a cloud security engineer role.

reason_behind_planning: This plan was structured to prioritize core courses early on, establishing a solid foundation in cybersecurity principles and technologies. The first semester introduces essential concepts, prerequisites for advanced electives. The second semester focuses on specialized knowledge in cloud security and system security, aligning with the student's goal of becoming a cloud security engineer. The third semester deepens understanding of network security and software vulnerabilities, critical areas for securing cloud environments. The final semester culminates in a capstone project that integrates all learned skills, emphasizing practical application and readiness for industry roles. Electives were carefully selected to complement core courses, providing practical and theoretical knowledge in cloud security, network protocols, cryptography, and vulnerabilities. Workload is balanced evenly across semesters, respecting the 8-credit limit, and prerequisites are respected by scheduling foundational courses first. This approach ensures a comprehensive, cohesive learning path aligned with the student's career goal.

courses.title: Application Engineering and Development
courses.description: Takes students in a step-by-step manner through the process of systematically combining UX techniques, business processes, and complex data models to assemble applications that are user-friendly and meet business requirements. Employs the object-oriented paradigm, visual user experience, and system design principles to put together complicated, powerful, real-world applications.
courses.reason: This foundational core course introduces essential application development techniques and system design principles, setting the stage for advanced Java and software engineering topics. It is scheduled early to build a strong base for subsequent courses.

courses.title: Concepts of Object-Oriented Design
courses.description: Introduces object-oriented design and programming via the Java programming language; the use of inheritance, composition, and interface classes in software design; development of Java applets and applications; study of the Java class libraries, including the swing toolkit for building human computer interfaces, the network package for development of client-server systems, and the collections package for data structures and sorting algorithms.
courses.reason: This course deepens understanding of Java and object-oriented principles, crucial for building scalable and maintainable software. It is scheduled early to prepare for more advanced design and multithreading courses.

courses.title: Enterprise Software Design
courses.description: Builds on object-oriented concepts with focus on architecture, design, and implementation of web-based, database-intensive applications using frameworks like Spring MVC, Hibernate, and jQuery.
courses.reason: This elective enhances web development skills, essential for Java-based enterprise applications, and complements prior courses by focusing on practical frameworks.

courses.title: Software Design Patterns and Engineering
courses.description: Covers design patterns such as Factory, Command, and Decorator, enabling students to write extensible, maintainable software. Uses industry best practices and real-world examples.
courses.reason: Design patterns are critical for writing robust Java code. This course builds on object-oriented design and prepares students for complex system development.

courses.title: Foundations of Parallel, Concurrent, and Multithreaded Programming
courses.description: Covers all aspects of concurrent program design, development, and implementation utilizing Java multithreading API. Topics include thread safety, synchronization, thread pools, deadlock, race conditions, and performance considerations.
courses.reason: Multithreading is essential for high-performance Java applications. This course provides practical skills for developing efficient, concurrent software.

courses.title: Application Modeling and Design
courses.description: Practices social-technical software engineering methods to build business applications, combining UX, business processes, and complex data models using Java and visual design principles.
courses.reason: This course reinforces application design skills with a focus on user-centric and data-driven development, essential for real-world Java applications.

courses.title: Master's Project
courses.description: Supports teamwork on a large software project under faculty supervision, involving design, systems engineering, and implementation. Covers significant parts of the software development lifecycle.
courses.reason: The capstone project consolidates learning from all courses, providing practical experience in managing a comprehensive Java-based software project.

courses.title: Web Development Tools and Methods
courses.description: Explores advanced server-side technologies and tools necessary to design and engineer complete web-based enterprise applications quickly. Designed to build on previous experience to cover the life cycle of a web-based application. Focuses on MVC web development frameworks to build server-side, data-intensive, and multitier web applications. Additionally, discusses designing rich internet applications (RIA) using AJAX and service-oriented architecture (SOA) using REST.
courses.prerequisites: Information Systems Program 5100 Graduate B- Or Information Systems Program 5100 Undergraduate B-

reason_behind_planning: This plan begins with foundational courses that introduce application development and object-oriented design, establishing core Java skills early. The second semester emphasizes enterprise web frameworks and design patterns, critical for modern Java applications. The third semester focuses on concurrency and application modeling, essential for high-performance and scalable systems. The final semester consolidates all learning through a comprehensive project, ensuring practical experience. Prerequisites are respected by scheduling foundational courses first, and electives are chosen to expand web development, design patterns, concurrency, and application modeling expertise. Workload is balanced evenly across semesters, with each term containing two courses totaling 8 credits, adhering to the constraints. The plan avoids repeating courses and ensures all core courses are included exactly once, with electives chosen to meet the minimum required credits and support the goal of becoming a proficient Java developer in software engineering.

courses.title: Application Engineering and Development
courses.description: Takes students in a step-by-step manner through the process of systematically combining UX techniques, business processes, and complex data models to assemble applications that are user-friendly and meet business requirements. Employs the object-oriented paradigm, visual user experience, and system design principles to put together complicated, powerful, real-world applications. The primary objective of this course is to practice social-technical software engineering methods and tools to solve real-world problems. Offers students an opportunity to learn innovative design and programming techniques to build significant business applications quickly; to practice simple and smart ways of making software construction enjoyable; and to master the art of how to systematically write software programs to solve any business problem.
courses.reason: This foundational course introduces the entire software engineering process, essential for understanding Java application development and system design, setting the stage for advanced topics.

courses.title: Concepts of Object-Oriented Design
courses.description: Introduces object-oriented design and programming via the Java programming language; the use of inheritance, composition, and interface classes in software design; development of Java applets and applications; study of the Java class libraries, including the swing tool kit for building human computer interfaces, the network package for development of client-server systems, and the collections’ package for data structures and sorting algorithms. Requires a course project. Requires knowledge of C programming.
courses.reason: This course deepens understanding of object-oriented principles and Java programming, crucial for becoming a proficient Java developer.

courses.title: Data Science Engineering with Python
courses.description: Studies the Python programming language with data science as the application domain. Offers students an opportunity to learn how to perform complex numerical calculations, fixed data types, space efficiency, and vector manipulations. Covers tools and techniques for manipulating tables, spreadsheets, and group and pivot tables involving extremely large data sets. Covers large multidimensional arrays and matrices and the high-level mathematical functions to operate on these arrays. Studies how to use Python to manipulate the classic math and science algorithms. Analyzes helper functions such as linear and nonlinear regression, integration, Fourier transformations, numerical optimization, etc. Includes higher-level classes for manipulating and visualizing data. Applies tools and techniques to classical data science using cases such as time series forecasting, social network analysis, text analytics, and big data processing.
courses.reason: This course introduces data manipulation and analysis skills using Python, complementing Java skills and broadening data science capabilities.

courses.title: Web Development Tools and Methods
courses.description: Explores advanced server-side technologies and tools necessary to design and engineer complete web-based enterprise applications quickly. Designed to build on previous experience to cover the life cycle of a web-based application. Focuses on MVC web development frameworks to build server-side, data-intensive, and multitier web applications. Additionally, discusses designing rich internet applications (RIA) using AJAX and service-oriented architecture (SOA) using REST.
courses.reason: This course enhances web development skills, essential for building modern Java-based web applications and understanding full-stack development.

courses.title: Software Design Patterns and Engineering
courses.description: Covers design patterns including Factory, Command, and Decorator. Design patterns allow software engineers to use abstraction to design software that is extensible, maintainable, and cost-effective. Each design pattern is implemented using industry best practices and shown to solve real-world problems. Uses a pragmatic teach-by-example/learn-by-doing methodology; lecture examples can be applied to any object-oriented language. Offers students an opportunity to master concepts and develop skills in a demystifying and easy-to-absorb format.
courses.reason: This course teaches essential design patterns, enabling the student to write scalable and maintainable Java code, a key skill for a Java developer.

courses.title: Elective
courses.description: Offers elective credit for courses taken at other academic institutions. May be repeated without limit.
courses.reason: Provides flexibility to explore additional topics aligned with Java development and software engineering.

courses.title: Advanced Application Engineering Project
courses.description: Offers students an opportunity to master advanced software design and programming techniques for building complex software applications quickly. The engineering issues addressed assume the business problems are difficult to understand and manage in a practical manner— the system capacity must support thousands or even millions of users in a multitude of roles. Addresses high-performance computing requirements such as concurrency and control, scalability, replication, and failover.
courses.reason: This capstone project consolidates all previous learning, emphasizing scalable, high-performance Java applications, preparing the student for real-world software engineering roles.

courses.title: Elective
courses.description: Offers elective credit for courses taken at other academic institutions. May be repeated without limit.

Electives are distributed to enhance Java and software engineering skills without repetition, ensuring a well-rounded, deep learning experience aligned with the goal of becoming a Java developer in software engineering.

courses.title: Software Engineering
courses.description: Looks at the software life cycle (requirements analysis and specification, software design, coding, testing, and maintenance). Offers verification, validation, and documentation at various stages of the life cycle. Covers the Unified Modeling Language as applied to the software life cycle. Covers applications of design patterns. Overviews user interface design, software metrics, and software development environments. Emphasis is on modular software construction and development of modular libraries. Requires a small software development project.
courses.reason: This elective introduces software engineering principles crucial for managing large Java projects and ensuring quality.

courses.title: Advanced Application Engineering Project
courses.description: Offers students an opportunity to master advanced software design and programming techniques for building complex software applications quickly. The engineering issues addressed assume the business problems are difficult to understand and manage in a practical manner—the system capacity must support thousands or even millions of users in a multitude of roles. Addresses high-performance computing requirements such as concurrency and control, scalability, replication, and failover.
courses.reason: This project course allows practical application of learned skills to complex, high-performance Java applications, preparing for real-world challenges.

courses.title: Advanced Cloud Computing
courses.description: Examines a collection of repeatable, generic software design patterns such as sidecar pattern, ambassador pattern, adapter pattern, event driven, stream and batch processing, containers and container orchestration with Kubernetes, replication, partitioning, transactions, consistency, and consensus to help make the development of reliable distributed systems more approachable and efficient. Microservices, containers, and container orchestration have fundamentally changed how distributed systems are developed. Offers students an opportunity to determine which kind of technology is appropriate for which purpose and to understand how these patterns can be combined to form the foundation of a good application architecture.
courses.reason: This course enhances understanding of cloud-native architectures and microservices, key for scalable Java backend systems.

courses.title: Master's Project
courses.description: Supports teamwork on a large software project under faculty supervision. The projects are drawn from an engineering field, and involve design, systems engineering, manufacturing, planning maintenance, reliability, quality control, risk assessment, project control, evaluation of alternatives, and so on. The project may cover either the whole software development life cycle or a significant part of it.
courses.reason: This capstone project synthesizes all previous learning into a comprehensive Java-based software engineering project, demonstrating mastery.

courses.title: Special Topics in Software Engineering Systems
courses.description: Offers topics of current interest in software engineering systems. May be repeated up to three times for a maximum of 16 semester hours.
courses.reason: Provides exposure to current advanced topics, keeping the student updated on latest trends relevant to Java and software engineering.

reason_behind_planning: This plan starts with foundational courses that introduce application engineering and object-oriented design, both critical for Java development. The first semester emphasizes core concepts and Java-specific design principles. The second semester expands into application modeling, system design, and software engineering practices, ensuring a comprehensive understanding of software development lifecycle and project management. The third semester focuses on advanced application engineering, cloud computing, and microservices architectures, aligning with modern Java backend development trends. The final semester culminates in a capstone project, allowing practical application of all learned skills in a large-scale, real-world software engineering project. Prerequisites are respected by scheduling foundational courses early, and electives are chosen to deepen understanding of object-oriented design, software engineering, cloud computing, and scalable architectures. Workload is balanced across semesters, maintaining 8 credits each, and all core courses are included exactly once, with the capstone positioned last to serve as a comprehensive demonstration of skills. The elective courses selected support the goal of becoming a proficient Java developer in scalable, cloud-native, and high-performance systems.

courses.title: Enterprise Software Design
courses.description: Designed to build on previous experience in concepts of object-oriented design courses with equal focus in the three areas of architecture, design, and implementation. Instruction and hands-on exercises cover both server-side and client-side web programming. Offers students an opportunity to build a conceptual understanding and to gain practical experience with popular frameworks (Spring MVC, Hibernate, and Dojo or jQuery) that increase productivity, empower developers, and greatly simplify web development. The goal is to be able to build the server side and client side of substantial web-based, client-server, database-intensive, multitier applications.
courses.reason: This course provides practical skills in web application architecture, essential for modern Java development and enterprise solutions.
