courses.title: Foundations of Parallel, Concurrent, and Multithreaded Programming
courses.description: Covers all aspects of concurrent program design, development, and implementation utilizing the Java multithreading API/facilities. Topics covered include thread safety and lifetime issues, block structured versus explicit synchronization, intrinsic versus explicit locking, thread pools, liveness issues, deadlock, livelock, race conditions, atomicity, performance and scalability, execution policies, test strategies. Major Java multithreading API/facilities covered include synchronized blocks, wait sets, intrinsic locks and condition variables, synchronized and concurrent collections, executor framework. Comparisons between the Java multithreading API and the Posix Pthreads multithreading standard are provided.
courses.reason: This course prepares the student to develop high-performance, concurrent Java applications, a vital skill for scalable enterprise software.

courses.title: Application Modeling and Design
courses.description: Practices social-technical software engineering methods and tools to solve real-world problems. Explores innovative design and programming techniques to build significant business applications quickly. Studies the process of systematically combining UX techniques, business processes, and complex data models to assemble applications that are user-friendly and meet business requirements. Employs the object-oriented paradigm, visual user interface design principles, and programming languages such as Java, as well as productivity tools, to put together complicated, powerful business applications with ease. Explores the art of how to systematically write software programs to solve any business problem, through practicing simple and smart ways of making software programming enjoyable.

reason_behind_planning: This four-semester plan begins with core foundational courses that introduce application engineering principles and object-oriented design, establishing a solid base for Java development. The first semester emphasizes understanding system design and Java programming fundamentals. The second semester builds on this with courses focused on enterprise web design and development tools, crucial for modern Java enterprise applications. The third semester introduces advanced application engineering projects and design patterns, fostering practical skills in building scalable, maintainable software. The final semester concentrates on concurrency and multithreading, essential for high-performance Java applications. Prerequisites are respected by sequencing courses accordingly, ensuring foundational knowledge before tackling advanced topics. Workload is balanced across semesters, with each semester containing two 4-credit courses, aligning with the 8-credit per semester constraint. The plan avoids repetition, includes all core courses, and incorporates at least six electives to meet credit requirements, ensuring comprehensive preparation for a Java development career in software engineering.

courses.title: Value Creation through Financial Decision Making
courses.description: Highlights the role of financial management as a source of value creation in a competitive global environment characterized by rapid technological, personal, and market changes. Offers students an opportunity to develop tools and techniques of financial analysis and valuation to support financial decision making. Presents future managers with actual business problems to learn to apply the tools of financial analysis to strategic decisions faced by the firm, such as capital budgeting and capital structure.
courses.reason: This foundational core course introduces key financial decision-making tools essential for understanding corporate finance, setting the stage for advanced topics.

courses.title: Analysis of Financial Institutions and Markets
courses.description: Introduces the domestic and international financial system and the institutions within it. Develops data and quantitative analysis tools utilized for economic and financial modeling and analysis. Emphasis is on regression analysis and its application, including how to build and interpret statistical models. Topics include the major types of financial institutions that operate within the global economy and the financial instruments employed by them; how exchange rates, interests rates, and security prices are determined and how governments and central banks impact economic and financial conditions.
courses.reason: This course provides a broad understanding of financial systems and markets, critical for advisory roles and understanding financial environments.

courses.title: Fundamentals of International Finance
courses.description: Presents the fundamental skills and techniques needed for the financial management of multinational firms. Offers students an opportunity to develop an understanding of the challenges and opportunities facing the financial manager in a global economy. Topics include operation of the foreign exchange markets, international parity conditions, multinational capital budgeting, and sources and instruments of international financing.
courses.prerequisites: ( Finance & Insurance 6418 Graduate C- And Finance & Insurance 6420 Graduate C- ) Or Finance & Insurance 6431 Graduate C-

courses.title: Investment Analysis
courses.description: Familiarizes students with domestic and international financial markets and the securities traded therein. Discusses a variety of techniques for valuation of financial assets and relies heavily on quantitative methods. Critically analyzes such qualitative concepts as market efficiency, intrinsic value, and risk. The contents of this course, descriptive, theoretical, and applied, should provide students with the ability to build unique valuation models to suit the particular investment alternative they wish to scrutinize. Also provides students with an understanding of how investment theory and investment practice relate.
courses.reason: This course deepens understanding of valuation and investment strategies, vital for corporate finance and advisory expertise.

courses.title: International Financial Management
courses.description: Develops specific concepts, policies, and techniques for the financial management of the multinational firm. Topics include operation of the foreign exchange markets, foreign exchange risk management, sources and instruments of international financing, foreign direct investment and the management of political risk, multinational capital budgeting, and financing control systems for the multinational firm.
courses.reason: This course equips students with international financial management skills, crucial for advising multinational corporations.

courses.title: Financial Data and Fintech
courses.description: Covers methods of managing data and extracting insights from real-world financial sources. Topics include extracting and organizing data from financial, geospatial, and supply chain sources; financial aggregation; and reporting. Applications include current and emergent data sources employed in finance, risk-weighted assets, market and credit risk modeling, stress testing, and climate risk. Studies major sources of financial data, data visualization, and architecture. Offers hands-on instruction in tools used in the financial industry to process datasets.

courses.title: Financial Strategy
courses.description: Develops financial, analytical, and communication skills necessary to develop and implement a financial strategy consistent with firm value creation in a dynamic environment. Stresses the impact of ethical and legal considerations, global markets, and technological innovation on efficient economic outcomes. Emphasizes written and oral communication skills. Upon completion of this course, students should be able to identify and analyze a firm’s strategic opportunities and propose a suitable financial strategy that is consistent with firm value creation.
courses.reason: This course synthesizes prior knowledge into strategic financial decision-making, preparing for advisory roles.

courses.title: Finance Seminar
courses.description: Structures discussion of current topics in the finance literature. Students read and present the works of leading researchers. Topics are broad and may cover various areas of corporate finance, investments, and institutions. Students also complete an original project emphasizing current methodologies of analysis.
courses.reason: This seminar exposes students to cutting-edge research and analytical methods in finance, enhancing advisory expertise.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Programming for Finance
courses.description: Introduces programming for finance and financial data analytics. Presents key concepts in programming, data structures, and data analysis with high-level programming language. Integrates data analytics libraries and tools with techniques for acquiring and combining data from different sources. Uses these tools and techniques to evaluate risk and return.

courses.title: Corporate Finance
courses.description: Introduces the basic framework of corporate finance and financial decision making. Topics include capital budgeting; capital investment decisions; complex valuations; security issues; dividend policy; static and dynamic capital structure; real option analysis; restructuring; bankruptcy; corporate control and governance; the legal, ethical, and regulatory environment of financial management; risk management; and mergers and acquisitions.
courses.reason: This elective provides in-depth knowledge of corporate financial decisions, essential for advisory roles and corporate finance expertise.

courses.title: Financial Data and Fintech
courses.description: Covers methods of managing data and extracting insights from real-world financial sources. Topics include extracting and organizing data from financial, geospatial, and supply chain sources; financial aggregation; and reporting. Applications include current and emergent data sources employed in finance, risk-weighted assets, market and credit risk modeling, stress testing, and climate risk. Studies major sources of financial data, data visualization, and architecture. Offers hands-on instruction in tools used in the financial industry to process datasets.
courses.reason: This elective enhances data management and fintech skills, vital for modern advisory roles and financial analysis.

courses.title: Advanced Real Estate Financial Modeling
courses.description: Explores real estate finance and modeling, building on foundational knowledge from prior coursework. Key focus areas include advanced real estate modeling techniques, complex mortgage financing, and securitized markets. Covers topics such as discounted cash flow models, investment return profiles, cap rate analysis, commercial mortgage-backed securities, REITs, and real estate private equity funds. Emphasizes the practical application of advanced financial analysis in real estate investment.
courses.reason: This elective provides specialized knowledge in real estate finance, broadening advisory capabilities in real estate markets.

courses.title: Financial Modeling
courses.description: Introduces financial modeling applications in the fields of financial risk management, statistics applied to finance, investments, and portfolio management. Offers students an opportunity to develop strong Excel proficiency needed to understand and implement the quantitative aspects of financial topics covered in the various courses taught in the MBA and MSF programs and to learn how to use a variety of spreadsheet tools and techniques to enhance their overall analytical skill set.
courses.reason: This elective strengthens practical financial modeling skills, essential for advisory roles and complex financial analysis.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Finance
courses.description: Examines current, specialized, and advanced topics in the areas of corporate finance, investments, risk management, valuation, private equity, venture capital, and other areas as appropriate. Course content, pedagogy, and prerequisites vary by topic and instructor.

reason_behind_planning: The plan begins with foundational core courses in the first semester to establish essential financial analysis and market understanding, respecting prerequisites and ensuring a solid base. The second semester continues with advanced financial and international management courses, deepening technical knowledge aligned with corporate finance and advisory skills. The third semester introduces strategic and research-oriented courses, fostering analytical and strategic thinking necessary for advisory roles. The fourth semester focuses on specialized elective courses in corporate finance and fintech, providing practical and contemporary skills for advisory firms. The final semester includes advanced real estate modeling and financial modeling courses, broadening expertise and practical application capabilities. Workload is balanced across semesters, with 6-7 credits each, avoiding overload. The sequence ensures all core courses are completed early, prerequisites are respected, and electives are added progressively to meet the required credits, culminating in a comprehensive skill set suitable for a career in corporate finance advisory roles.

courses.title: Financing Innovation and Growth
courses.description: Offers an immersion in corporate finance with a specific focus on the financing of innovation and growth at firms. Topics include analyzing and applying finance from the perspective of intrapreneurship as well as entrepreneurship.
courses.reason: This elective focuses on financing innovation and growth, key for advisory roles in innovative and high-growth firms, scheduled in the final semester to complement previous learning.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Finance
courses.description: Examines current, specialized, and advanced topics in the areas of corporate finance, investments, risk management, valuation, private equity, venture capital, and other areas as appropriate. Course content, pedagogy, and prerequisites vary by topic and instructor.

reason_behind_planning: The plan begins with foundational core courses in the first two semesters, ensuring a solid understanding of financial management, markets, and international finance. These are scheduled early to build the necessary background for advanced topics. Semesters 3 and 4 incorporate more strategic and specialized courses, including the finance seminar and core electives like Corporate Finance and Financial Data/Fintech, which are crucial for developing expertise aligned with advisory roles. The electives are chosen to deepen knowledge in corporate finance, data analytics, and innovative financing, all essential for a career in advisory firms. The workload is balanced across semesters, respecting the 6-8 credit range, with the final semester dedicated to specialized electives to enhance practical and strategic skills. Prerequisites are respected by sequencing courses accordingly, and all core courses are included exactly once. The total credits are maintained within the 30-31 range, and the plan fits within the 4-5 semester window, providing a comprehensive pathway to becoming an expert in corporate finance and securing a role in advisory firms.

courses.title: Analysis of Financial Institutions and Markets
courses.description: Introduces the domestic and international financial system and the institutions within it. Develops data and quantitative analysis tools utilized for economic and financial modeling and analysis. Emphasis is on regression analysis and its application, including how to build and interpret statistical models. Topics include the major types of financial institutions that operate within the global economy and the financial instruments employed by them; how exchange rates, interests rates, and security prices are determined and how they affect the global economy; and how governments and central banks impact economic and financial conditions.
courses.reason: This foundational course provides essential understanding of financial systems, crucial for portfolio management, and is scheduled early to serve as a prerequisite for advanced finance courses.

courses.title: Value Creation through Financial Decision Making
courses.description: Highlights the role of financial management as a source of value creation in a competitive global environment characterized by rapid technological, personal, and market changes. Offers students an opportunity to develop tools and techniques of financial analysis and valuation to support financial decision making. Presents future managers with actual business problems to learn to apply the tools of financial analysis to strategic decisions faced by the firm, such as capital budgeting and capital structure.
courses.reason: This core course develops critical financial decision-making skills necessary for portfolio management and is scheduled early to build a strong foundation.

courses.title: Quantitative Portfolio Management
courses.description: Introduces portfolio management with a focus on quantitative methods. Major topics include the construction, rebalancing, and performance measurement of active equity portfolios. Examines portfolio construction using constrained mean-variance optimization, as well as performance evaluation using multi-factor models of risk such as the Fama-French three-factor model. Additional topics include the effects of diversification on risk reduction, transaction cost management, and style attribution. Also covers quantitative approaches to manage specific sources of risk. Course is applied and MATLAB based, and students employ historical data to backtest and assess the performance of various portfolio strategies.

courses.title: Investment Analysis
courses.description: Familiarizes students with domestic and international financial markets and the securities traded therein. Discusses a variety of techniques for valuation of financial assets and relies heavily on quantitative methods. Critically analyzes such qualitative concepts as market efficiency, intrinsic value, and risk. The contents of this course, descriptive, theoretical, and applied, should provide students with the ability to build unique valuation models to suit the particular investment alternative they wish to scrutinize. Also provides students with an understanding of how investment theory and investment practice relate.
courses.reason: Key for understanding asset valuation and investment strategies, scheduled after foundational courses to deepen technical skills.

courses.title: International Financial Management
courses.description: Develops specific concepts, policies, and techniques for the financial management of the multinational firm. Topics include operation of the foreign exchange markets, foreign exchange risk management, sources and instruments of international financing, foreign direct investment and the management of political risk, multinational capital budgeting, and financing control systems for the multinational firm.
courses.reason: Provides international context essential for global portfolio management, scheduled after core valuation courses.

courses.title: Financial Modeling
courses.description: Introduces financial modeling applications in the fields of financial risk management, statistics applied to finance, investments, and portfolio management. Offers students an opportunity to develop strong Excel proficiency needed to understand and implement the quantitative aspects of financial topics covered in the various courses taught in the MBA and MSF programs and to learn how to use a variety of spreadsheet tools and techniques to enhance their overall analytical skill set.
courses.prerequisites: Finance & Insurance 6418 Graduate C- Or Finance & Insurance 6420 Graduate C-

courses.title: Financial Strategy
courses.description: Develops financial, analytical, and communication skills necessary to develop and implement a financial strategy consistent with firm value creation in a dynamic environment. Stresses the impact of ethical and legal considerations, global markets, and technological innovation on efficient economic outcomes. Emphasizes written and oral communication skills. Upon completion of this course, students should be able to identify and analyze a firm’s strategic opportunities and propose a suitable financial strategy that is consistent with firm value creation.
courses.reason: Critical for understanding strategic financial decisions in portfolio management, scheduled after core courses to integrate knowledge.

courses.title: Finance Seminar
courses.description: Structures discussion of current topics in the finance literature. Students read and present the works of leading researchers. Topics are broad and may cover various areas of corporate finance, investments, and institutions. Students also complete an original project emphasizing current methodologies of analysis.
courses.reason: Enhances research and current trends understanding, scheduled after core courses to prepare for advanced electives.

courses.title: Fixed-Income Securities
courses.description: Exposes students to theory, applications, and evidence concerning interest-rate products. Designed for students seeking to understand fixed-income valuation and hedging methods and to become familiar with major markets and instruments. Analyzes the concepts of interest-rate risk and credit risk. Discusses recent developments in pension fund management, asset/liability management, duration matching, and gap management.

courses.title: Quantitative Portfolio Management
courses.description: Offers an introduction to portfolio management with a focus on quantitative methods. Major topics include portfolio construction, revision, and performance measurement. Examines portfolio construction using constrained mean-variance optimization, as well as performance evaluation using factor models such as the Fama-French three-factor model. Additional topics include the effects of diversification on risk reduction and the costs of inflation, taxes, and transaction costs on management of fixed-income and equity security portfolios. Also covers quantitative approaches to manage specific sources of risk. Students employ historical data to construct backtests to assess the performance of various portfolio strategies.
courses.reason: Introduces quantitative portfolio techniques essential for becoming an expert, scheduled in the final semester to build on prior finance knowledge.

courses.title: Portfolio Construction and Management
courses.description: Introduces portfolio construction, management, and reporting with applications in a high-level programming language such as Python, focusing on low-volatility and risk parity investing styles. Students complete two miniprojects that involve position sizing, portfolio rebalancing, stress testing, risk limits, and portfolio reporting.
courses.reason: Practical application of portfolio management skills with programming, scheduled last to consolidate learning.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Financial Math and Financial Markets
courses.description: Introduces the essential mathematical tools required for modern finance and their application in a high-level programming language. Emphasizes both theoretical concepts and empirical evidence crucial for informed investment decisions. Key topics include linear algebra, calculus (single and multivariable), optimization theory, probability, statistics, and stochastic processes. Empirical subjects include the present value of money, the capital asset pricing model, mean-variance optimization, asset price dynamics, and option pricing.
courses.reason: Provides mathematical and empirical foundation necessary for advanced quantitative portfolio management, scheduled in the final semester.

Workload is balanced with 6 to 8 credits per semester, avoiding overload while ensuring comprehensive coverage of essential topics. Electives are chosen to complement and extend core knowledge, with a focus on quantitative methods, portfolio construction, and financial mathematics, critical for becoming an expert in portfolio management. courses.title: Evaluating and Managing Financial Investments
courses.description: Introduces the menu of financial assets available to investors and how these assets can be combined into optimal portfolios to meet different objectives. Presents an overview of the primary asset classes, the markets in which these assets trade, and the investment companies that manage portfolios. Focuses on quantifying the rates of return and levels of risk associated with individual investments and diversified portfolios. Offers students an opportunity to develop models of asset valuation to calculate equilibrium prices for debt and equity securities. Studies how actively managed portfolios can exploit mispricing and how investors should evaluate the performance of a managed portfolio.

courses.description: Exposes students to theory, applications, and evidence concerning highly sensitive interest rate products. Discusses recent developments in pension fund management, asset/liability management, duration matching, “gap” management, concurrent interest rate and exchange rate management, and other important issues now confronting domestic and international financial and corporate management. Studies how to customize a risk management program.
